subSections.title: Readings
Etymology 1
subSections.text:
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=o|じ}}
From {{bor|ja|ltc|sort=じ|匙|tr=zhiɛ||spoon}}. The [[呉音#Japanese|''goon'']], so likely the earliest borrowing from {{cog|ltc|-}}.

subSections.title: Derived terms
Etymology 2
subSections.text:
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=o|し}}
From {{bor|ja|ltc|-|sort=じ}} {{m|zh|匙|tr=zhiɛ||spoon}}. The [[漢音#Japanese|''kan'on'']], so a later borrowing. Compare modern {{cog|yue|匙|tr=ci<sup>4</sup>}}, {{cog|nan|匙|tr=sî}}.

subSections.title: Derived terms
Etymology 3
subSections.text:
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=o|ひ}}
Likely an alteration of the [[漢音#Japanese|''kan'on'']] reading ''shi'': {{IPAchar|/si/}} → {{IPAchar|/hi/}}

subSections.title: Derived terms
Etymology 4
Noun
subSections.text:
{{ja-noun|かい|hhira=かひ}}

# {{lb|ja|sort=かい|obsolete}} a [[scoop]] for [[food]]
# {{lb|ja|sort=かい|archaic|rare}} a [[wooden]] [[sword]] for [[training]]
#: This sense developed from an [[ateji]] spelling of {{ja-l|木刀}} (literally, “wooden blade”) applied to the ''[[food]] [[scoop]]'' meaning.

subSections.title: Derived terms
Etymology 5
Noun
Usage notes
subSections.text:
In modern Japanese, the term {{ja-r|スプーン}} is used to refer to spoons in general, including spoons as found in the Western world. The term ''saji'' generally refers more to the broad, usually flat-bottomed Asian-style spoon shown at right.

The ''saji'' reading is the most common in modern Japanese when using this term as a standalone noun. The kanji spelling ({{lang|ja|匙}}) is rarely encountered; it is usually written in hiragana alone ({{lang|ja|さじ}}).

subSections.title: Derived terms
subSections.text:
{{der-top}}
* {{ja-r|石匙|いし さじ}}: {{qualifier|neolithic}} a [[stone]] [[spoon]] or [[scoop]]
* {{ja-r|大匙|おおさじ}}: a large [[spoon]] or [[scoop]], a [[ladle]]; a [[tablespoon]], a unit of measure of 15ml
* {{ja-r|御匙|おさじ}}: a [[spoon]] {{qualifier|polite speech}}; a [[doctor]] {{qualifier|especially one tending to a high-ranking [[samurai]] family}}
* {{ja-r|御匙医師|おさじ いし}}: a [[doctor]] {{qualifier|especially one tending to a high-ranking [[samurai]] family}}
* {{ja-r|香匙|こう さじ}}: an [[incense]] [[scoop]]
* {{ja-r|小匙|こさじ}}: a small [[spoon]] or [[scoop]]; a [[teaspoon]], a unit of measure of 5ml
* {{ja-l|匙沢瀉}}, {{ja-r|匙面高|さじおもだか}}: a [[perennial]] [[flowering]] [[plant]], {{taxlink|Alisma plantago-aquatica var. orientale|subspecies|noshow=1}} ({{vern|common water plantain}}, {{vern|mad-dog weed}})
* {{ja-r|匙加減|さじかげん}}: literally, “spoon moderation”: the degree of [[skill]] in [[compounding]] [[medicine]]; a [[doctor]]'s method of [[treatment]]; the [[balance]] of [[flavor]]s in a [[dish]]; [[knack]] or [[finesse]] in doing something
* {{ja-r|匙が回る|さじ が まわる}}: {{sense|idiom}} “the spoon goes around” → to be [[skillful]] at compounding medicine
* {{ja-r|匙先|さじさき}}: literally, “spoon tip”: the degree of [[skill]] in [[compounding]] [[medicine]]; a [[doctor]]'s [[skill]] in treatment
* {{ja-r|匙を投げる|さじ を なげる}}: {{sense|idiom}} “throw the spoon” → [[throw in the towel]]
* {{ja-r|茶匙|ちゃ さじ}}: a [[teaspoon]] {{qualifier|a spoon used for tea}}; a [[teaspoon]], a unit of measure of 5ml
* {{ja-r|角匙|つの さじ}}: a [[spoon]] made from [[horn]], such as a [[cow]]'s horn, used historically when working with [[medicine]]s
* {{ja-r|灰匙|はい さじ}}: a [[spoon]] or [[scoop]] used to scoop out ashes from the [[brazier]] used for [[tea ceremony]]
* {{ja-r|浜匙|はまさじ}}: a [[perennial]] [[plant]], {{taxlink|Limonium tetragonum|species|noshow=1}} ({{vern|autumn statice}} or {{vern|square-stem statice}})
* {{ja-r|一匙飯|ひとさじ めし}}: a single [[scoop]] of cooked rice {{qualifier|viewed as inadequate and bad luck to eat just this amount, with some superstitions that eating just this would cause one to become a stepmother or stepchild}}
{{der-bottom}}

Etymology 6
subSections.text:
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|しゃじ}}
Appears to be an alteration of ''saji'' above: {{IPAchar|[sad͡ʑi]}} → {{IPAchar|[ɕad͡ʑi]}}<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref><ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref><ref name="DJS">{{R:Daijisen}}</ref>

subSections.title: Usage notes
subSections.text: This reading does not appear to be as common as the ''saji'' reading above. May be [[dialectal]].

subSections.title: Etymology 7
Usage notes
subSections.text: Although the general term ''sukui'' can serve as a standalone noun, this particular {{lang|ja|匙}} spelling for ''sukui'' is only found in compounds.
